page.title: 01GENERAL REVIEW OF AREA
page.content: {Upper Hartfield}in the north-east is an extension of{Hartfield. Coleman's {Hatch,}a separate village has a church under the jurisdiction of the Hartfield Rector. The area lies between 250 and 650 feet above sea level and is a mixture of open and wooded land. The extreme NW corner touches the River Medway and the disused railway, used as a footpath, runs along this valley. The main industry of this area is agriculture, cattle, sheep, riding stables and arable. There are many large houses some formerly farmhouses. The arable farms have seasonal work put out to contractors, hence farm workers cottages are now inhabited by commuters to London or nearby towns. In the south of the area is{Ashdown {Forest}owned by the Earl De Le Warr and administered by Conservators.
